name: David Chen
title: Pay was good. Transparency and communication from upper management not so much.
pros: The pay was good and I loved the people with whom I worked. I also greatly appreciated not having a manager looking over my shoulder and was able to own my career. There was enough variety in my job duties to keep the work interesting.
cons: Lots of hours. Doing an excellent job on regular tasks is not recognized. Shifts in headcount were unnecessary and harmful to the company. Intel should strive to avoid the boom and bust cycle -- much energy is put into training people and then it takes time for them to gain experience. Then there's a brain drain when management decides a headcount reduction is needed. Then we have to train people over again. I went through 4 cycles of headcount reductions in 10 years -- I left voluntarily at the last one partly because I was tired of the ups and downs; promotions are hard to come by even when receiving good performance reviews. Education figures into grade level more than experience (at Intel) does, when it should be the other way around.
advice_to_management: Stop boom and bust cycle -- hire in moderation and plan on keeping employees around for the long haul. Have managers evaluate each employee in their group and rank according to value to the organization, and ensure that grade level is consistent with that ranking (if person A has a higher value than person B, then person A's grade level should be higher than person B, or at least the same). The culture is inflexible and constrains innovation; Intel likes to hire people fresh out of school. I saw very few people come from other companies, which is unfortunate as an injection of fresh perspective could be helpful.

name: Michael Zhang
title: Good place to work. Recent industry headwinds causing a lot of pain.
pros: Decent pay and benefits. Smart coworkers. Most are friendly and easy to get along with. Intel has a long history of achievement. Room to rise if you are in a development group and are willing to put in time and effort.
cons: Differing orgs have differing situations. Some projects weren't well organized, so we spent too much time getting too little done. Too many meetings. Too many interruptions from late stage requirements changes and too much multitasking. Some of this was resolved by newer project managers.
advice_to_management: For employees expected to do 'deep work' like architecture, design or validation, avoid too many assignments in parallel. No matter how valuable any particular task is, each task is an interruption to the 'deep work' of the other tasks. Don't overload them. Managers can manage many sub-tasks, but each employee who is expected to do 'deep work' should have enough uninterrupted time. Don't waste our time with too many non-productive meetings. Any meeting you schedule should have a pre-announced agenda and require only the necessary people with a well-defined outcome.

name: Sarah Martinez
title: The CEO and CxO's are the real problem
pros: Once a great company. Benefits are ok, some nice and smart people.
cons: Frankly the CEO has no idea about what he is doing. Company has no strategy and direction. There was a reason he was let go many years ago. And he has proven times and times again he is one of the worst tech CEO's in the last two decades. CEO has been also misleading and feeding employees with misinformation for almost three years. Almost all of his CxO or senior management hires are fundamentally wrong, most of them have little industry experience and have been destroying the company's culture. SMG org has collapsed and its leader is like a cartoon character. CMO has no idea about modern marketing and has zero experience in hardware. The person who caused Data Center Business to collapse has been rewarded to become a CEO of an Intel company while hardest working senior managers were let go. Company has been spending on absurd things but they asked employees to give away %5 to 10% of their salaries. No rewards, promotions or bonuses given in multiple cycles. Salary is mediocre compared to competition. You don't even get coffee for free. It is a mental trap and employees have been stuck on endless lay-off cycles for years now. The company has no future and can't compete.
advice_to_management: Find a new CEO, and get rid of all senior management hires of this CEO.

name: James Wilson
title: A horrific tale of complete and utter failure
pros: 4 weeks sabbatical every 4 years. 4 weeks - paternity leave. 24 weeks - maternity leave. 20 + 3 vacation days per year (10+ years). Unlimited sick leaves.
cons: Self-serving employees and managers. No standards for hiring - frequent backdoor hiring, nepotism. Software engineering has no real substance, often just academic. CPU HW engineers are narrow-minded, pretentious, and arrogant. Lacking common sense engineering, perspective, and innovation. Management will intentionally change the goalpost as and when it pleases; as a power grab mechanism and will often remain behind the curtains to hide its own incompetence. Rock-bottom compensation. 80-85% of the company is deadweight doing busy work to please their boss, who is aiming to please his/her boss and so on to move up the job hierarchy.
advice_to_management: 80-85% of company is deadweight doing busy work to please their boss, who is aiming to please his/her boss and so on to move up the job hierarchy.

name: Emily Patel
title: Mixed Feelings
pros: 7% company matching for 401k. You get to be able to have some experience in the VLSI industry as a recent graduate.
cons: Roles are very narrow, meaning you won't get exposure to what is happening around you or even if you do, not enough to be able to learn much from it. Culture is extremely political and only the people who 'talk a good game' get promoted. Managers are the worst that I have seen in the industry, they do not know how to cultivate talent so naturally a lot of people leave after gaining some experience in what they want to do in other companies. No merit rewards, pay is way under compared to the market. High performers will only get promotions if they try to leave the company or if they get lucky with a decent manager. Most managers just continue delaying promotions due to 'company struggles.' No good system to track achievements. A lot of 'do not step into my territory' roles, meaning that there is a lot of siloed data and design techniques that only some people have but do not share. Blaming culture.
advice_to_management: Improve the internal promotion and merit recognition system, and ensure managers cultivate and retain talent effectively.

name: Robert Johnson
title: Big corporation with big corporate feel
pros: Benefits are great, lots of resources and impressive support structure to enable your success across the board. Many areas to explore if you aren't happy with your current role, and open to moving you if you need to. Workers seem cared for and taken care of in every aspect.
cons: Ridiculous rules and rigidity. Millions of classes, signs everywhere warning you about holding the hand rail so you don't die. Depending on your department there are meetings every hour. Pressure comes from the chain as expected given Intel's performance in the market lately. Generally not a very entrepreneurial company, and you can feign innovation and creativity to get ahead even when you haven't done a lot. No one who makes decisions is spending their own money, so like most big companies, there ends up being a lot of bloat and lack of efficiency. Because of this, a lot of employees manufacture work so they stay relevant and no one wants to admit there are too many people doing the same job.
advice_to_management: Bring some small business and entrepreneurial spirit into the business, and move past the over-the-top rigidity and employee brainwashing attempts.

name: Thomas Anderson
title: Not the best, not the worst
pros: The company is generous with PTO and working flexibility. For the most part, the people you work with are a joy to work with.
cons: Management is hesitant/slow to act when poor performance is brought to their attention, engineering fails to listen/is slow to listen to the experienced technicians on tool and safety issues, and corporate leadership consistently implants policies that lower morale.
advice_to_management: Listen to employees more and act promptly on safety and performance issues.

name: Jennifer Lee
title: Pay was good. Transparency and communication from upper management not so much.
pros: The pay was good and I loved the people with whom I worked. I also greatly appreciated not having a manager looking over my shoulder and was able to own my career. There was enough variety in my job duties to keep the work interesting.
cons: Lots of hours. Doing an excellent job on regular tasks is not recognized. Shifts in headcount were unnecessary and harmful to the company. Intel should strive to avoid the boom and bust cycle -- much energy is put into training people and then it takes time for them to gain experience. Then there's a 'brain drain' when management decides a headcount reduction is needed. Then we have to train people over again. I went through 4 cycles of headcount reductions in 10 years -- I left voluntarily at the last one partly because I was tired of the ups and downs; promotions are hard to come by even when receiving good performance reviews. Education figures into grade level more than experience (at Intel) does, when it should be the other way around.
advice_to_management: Stop boom and bust cycle -- hire in moderation and plan on keeping employees around for the long haul. Have managers evaluate each employee in their group and rank according to value to the organization, and ensure that grade level is consistent with that ranking (if person A has a higher value than person B, then person A's grade level should be higher than person B, or at least the same). The culture is inflexible and constrains innovation; Intel likes to hire people fresh out of school. I saw very few people come from other companies, which is unfortunate as an injection of fresh perspective could be helpful.

name: Kevin Wang
title: Experience
pros: It was a great place to work, with a positive and supportive environment that made each day enjoyable. The team I was in was collaborative and efficient, which contributed to a productive workflow and a sense of accomplishment. Additionally, the city's convenient transportation system made commuting smooth and hassle-free, adding to the overall positive experience.
cons: No significant negatives to mention due to limited time spent at the company.

name: Maria Rodriguez
title: Good Ideas, Bad Execution
pros: Great benefits. Health insurance is best in the state. Interesting work.
cons: Working for Intel startup fab for a little over 2 years now with a bachelor in chemical engineering. On call is 24/7 365 days a year. Depending on staffing could mean 1 week of on call every 2 months or every other week. The area you are in also affects how much you get called, could be every 60 min at night or essentially not at all. Engineering hours are 7am-4pm but if you are an exempt employee you will be asked to work anytime and any hours - without any extra compensation. Engineer working hours are not tracked by clock in/clock out. Which can be beneficial depending which area you work in. If you can get your work done in 15hrs per week that's fine. But you could be asked to work 80 hrs per week or transition to weekends or night shift.
advice_to_management: Calm the f down. Your lack of planning is not my emergency.

name: Daniel Kim
title: Great Benefits but absolute life, health, and metal killer.
pros: Pay, benefits, and flexibility to WFH. The WFH flexibility allows employees to connect and adapt to issues in the FAB without having to spend hours on the road and rush into the office to contain the issues. Process Engineering work is great and you get to experiment, research, analyze galore of data and help improve equipment and manufacturing. Pay is competitive and benefits are excellent.
cons: Work life balance for Process Engineer is basically out the door especially with family and young kids. The on-call 7/24 used to be good with a large team back late 2010 through the pre-pandemic. Basically, now, you can count on an average of about 4 to 5 hours of sleep. Expect to be called in the middle of the night to address issues.
advice_to_management: More Process Engineers per department and limit the number of equipment to maintain per engineer. Need to eliminate on-call or go back to once a 2 to 3 month rotation. Need to hire more Technicians to cover all shifts.

name: Rachel Thompson
title: You should read the hidden things
pros: They treat you well and have good culture.
cons: Layoffs are continuous. Your manager could be tricky to let you do low-profile things then blame you for lack of skills. Management is continuously causing problems to you, they cut salaries, make you and your family in pain for several months every year because of the layoffs.
advice_to_management: CEO is a good actor. Culture is good but fake.

name: Christopher Brown
title: Avoid working here!
pros: Gain some experience like anywhere else. Pay/benefits slightly above average.
cons: Expected to work on the weekends. Burden of fixing everything pushed onto you. Managers that do nothing but take home a high salary and ask engineers, 'is it ready yet?' Absolutely no hope to fix corruption and poor roadmap planning spanning from basic middle managers to the C-suite.
advice_to_management: Too much to fix, you won't change anything anyways; it's impossible for management to change anything when you hire completely incompetent 'leaders.' Stop paying large sums of money to 'consulting' companies like McKinsey to use as a scapegoat for mass layoffs.

name: Andrew Miller
title: Join at your own risk
pros: On-site Cafe is nice but getting expensive.
'Free' 24 hour Gym. You pay with your hard work hehe.
Impossible to get fired unless you are unsafe.
Health care is amazing and free if you take the HDHP. PPO is fairly cheap as well.
Culture is good. Very positive even with the poo storm we are in.
Amazing work life balance. Lots of PTO and if you work the shift schedule, you have 3 and 4 day weekends.
cons: Pay is not great compared to other companies.
Too many managers. We have managers for manager for manager for managers.
Culture! Even though it's good. The overall culture is to be as lazy and slow as possible. Very slow progress.
Some benefits have been cut/reduced due to the ongoing poo storm and there is no word on them being restored.
Expensive food in the Cafe.
If you don't have a degree, you won't go far in the company.
If you are an hourly employee, you don't get holidays off unless it's on your weekend.
advice_to_management: Use your manager skills to develop your team. Don't just follow the Intel handbook on how to be a manager. Too many bad/fake managers who should not have the role.

name: Michelle Garcia
title: A company under reconstruction
pros: Benefits. Intel has a competitive advantage over production volume, alliances with PC manufacturers, own factories (Fabs) for the production of processors, which allows it to enter with greater ease the new technology.
cons: Bureaucracy and slow pace, lay off concerns, no longer the leader in field and management.
advice_to_management: Be more supportive.

name: Steven Taylor
title: Intel Yield Engineer
role: PTD module and integration device yield engineer
pros: Good benefits.
Flexible time-off.
Hybrid/Work from home opportunities.
Movement within company.
cons: Uncertain future of company.
Work-life balance can be bad.
Can be high stress.

name: Amanda White
title: WAS great
pros: Interesting projects, great managers & team-mates, schedule flexibility, lots of freedom/trust/individual responsibility in specific team.
cons: Tough to get promotions, CEO turnover and executive leadership chaos. Eliminated sabbatical. Dropped from Dow Jones, stock in free fall.
advice_to_management: Board of directors has been a problem - short-sightedness, and they bear responsibility for selection and turn-over of CEO which in turn has led to squandering of opportunities and talent. Gelsinger is now the latest scapegoat and if he couldn't course-correct Intel, I don't believe yet another CEO chosen by the same board will have success. I actually liked Gelsinger.

name: Jessica Park
title: Work Life Balance
pros: Intel ensures that employees have the support they need to maintain their well-being and manage their personal lives effectively, through support programs such as wellness programs, mental health resources, and family support services, leading to increased job satisfaction and productivity.
Flexible work arrangements including remote work options and flexible hours.
cons: None at the moment as the work life balance is next to none.

name: Richard Davis
title: A good individual contributor role for Mid-Senior level employees.
pros: It is a good role for people who have some experience with commodity management and would like to develop themselves in this area. Company provides freedom to manage, trainings and tools to do it. If you have been employed during the post COVID era, the salaries are somewhat above the average.
cons: Company has been through 2 cycles of layoffs and voluntary leave programs in the last 2 years. Organizations are changing every other 6 months, leaving the remaining employees with more workload. Every layoff comes with at least 6 months of freeze period meaning, no new hires, promotions, bonus and salary increase.
advice_to_management: Management should find a way to motivate employees. The other companies are now poaching the company talent pool.

name: William Scott
title: Not the same Intel
pros: Decent pay and benefits including a sabbatical.
Extremely smart engineers.
Diverse.
On-site perks.
cons: Intel lost its 'only the paranoid survive' vision.
There are too many managers.
Lots of red tape and an insane philosophy of 'on a need-to-know basis.'
If you are an exempt employee, be prepared to do some work on weekends and nights.
advice_to_management: Make a decision for crying out loud. Help remove block roads, eliminate redundant meetings, and as a group, stop asking the same questions to the same POC. You are a source of waste.

name: Elizabeth Turner
title: Honest work with mismanagement
pros: Flexible schedule: WFH or in-office, as long as you got your task done and were available for others when they expected, it didn't matter what hours or from where you were working. Lots of accommodation for and around holidays.
Dedicated testing: There are dedicated test teams to write their own test cases, and dev-ops to help enable you to write your own test cases.
Good compensation: The base salary was high and the benefits were good. Health insurance, ESPP, RSU, annual bonus, gift-cards, in-house cafeteria/gym.
Senior engineers: There are many very talented senior engineers who have been with Intel for a long time.
cons: Wasted man-hours: Projects and features that had many engineers working on them for many months were often cancelled.
Low moral: My personal experience was feeling lied to by management. The details of lay-offs seemed almost intentionally vague.
Low opportunity for growth: I don't think I saw anyone on my team promoted in the years I worked at Intel.
advice_to_management: More transparency and rewards for hard work.

name: Joseph Clark
title: Futuristic products, Stone-Age culture
pros: If I could say, 'looking past the red tape,' I would, but then I'd be implying that's a possibility in the first place.
cons: The cons of working at Intel are there aren't any pros.
advice_to_management: Burn your middle management to the ground and start over—nobody tells the truth to leadership, and the amount of feudalistic backstabbing is enough to make Brutus or Judas look like role models.

name: Ryan Adams
title: If I'd known where Intel was headed I would've declined the job offer
pros: I LOVE my team, genuinely they are some of my favorite people.
Pay is decent.
Health benefits are quite good.
cons: Management/executives have no idea how things in the fab actually work.
Work environment is very tumultuous.
All the benefits they proudly brag about are now being stripped away.
advice_to_management: Every executive should be forced to work as a maintenance technician for at least three months.

name: Lauren Hill
title: Sinking ship
pros: Compensation is generous. They offer a matching 5% 401k and annual and quarterly bonuses.
cons: All benefits were scaled back or paused. They are struggling to stay profitable.

name: Brandon Cooper
title: Bureaucratic Pathology to the highest level (Most Toxic)
pros: They haven't gone bankrupt yet.
cons: Rules exist purely to maintain power structures.
Systems that punish innovation or improvement attempts.
advice_to_management: Good job firing Pat, now need a 3/4 company purge like Twitter. So much deadweight it's incredible.

name: Samantha Green
title: Decent Place to Work
pros: Teams are fairly conducive with cross-discipline coordination and activities.
cons: Many benefits have been diminished as part of austerity measures including free coffee and the sabbatical program.
advice_to_management: Take care of your employees you'd like to remain onboard financially and stop low-balling new hires.

name: Peter Morgan
title: Good company, just needs to take accountability and weed out the poor performance workers
pros: Cool and interesting work. Good work/life balance along with decent pay and benefits.
cons: Lots of people who should be fired because they 'milk' the system.
Safety priority is too much, causing negative impacts on production.
advice_to_management: Stop pointing fingers everywhere else for the blame and take accountability.

name: Michael Thompson
title: Constant re-org, hiring, then layoffs
pros: Generally not micromanaged.
Decent benefits.
Only US Semiconductor company, US government is invested in keeping them from going under.
cons: Company doesn't value seniority.
There are constant re-orgs, massive overhiring, then layoffs.
Doesn't make changes when needed.
Lack of quick decision making.
Removal of multiple benefits.
advice_to_management: Value people who actually stick with the company for years, rather than discarding them as if they're valueless. If something needs to be changed or updated - do it!

name: Sarah Williams
title: Hard Times
pros: Intel strives for a work culture that welcomes everyone.
The benefits are the best I have ever seen.
Intel is big on ergonomics.
cons: The company is currently in financial hardship.
Toxic admin culture in some pockets.
Gossip and lack of support among admins.
advice_to_management: Management needs to recognize unique skillsets and let go of employees for poor performance.

name: David Chen
title: Great company but, old talent
pros: Flexibility.
Scope of job.
Tuition reimbursement.
cons: Too many old people.
Processes are old and outdated.
Way too many acronyms that aren't necessary.
advice_to_management: Stop the acronyms and update legacy systems with what the industry is using.

name: Robert Anderson
title: Once great company, now on a decline
pros: Intel has been one of the best companies to work for in the last several decades.
Has been offering employees some of the best benefits all around.
cons: Lost competitiveness in recent years.
Hit by competition from all angles.
Taking reactionary actions to get back on track.
Huge layoffs and spending cuts.
advice_to_management: Stop hiring too many high-level managers from outside and stop promoting too many folks to VP.

name: James Wilson
title: Lead responsibilities, Sr Pay
pros: Easy to WFH.
Generous benefits (used to be).
Time off limited by Manager (sick leave unlimited, within reason).
cons: No upward movement.
Company politics.
Diversity initiatives that bypass merit.
advice_to_management: Stop having so many layers of management; promote those who actually do the work.

name: Jennifer Martinez
title: Attitude and ethic
pros: Intel is a big company with lots of opportunities for proactive employees with good work ethic.
cons: If you are a complainer or feel entitled, you won't be happy anywhere.
Company suffers from imbalance diversity vs employee skills.
advice_to_management: Talk to, represent, and support your employees. Their success is Intel's success.

name: Thomas Lee
title: Too many uneducated managers, lab thieves, alcoholics, druggies, incompetence
pros: Honestly, I can't think of any.
cons: Too many uneducated managers.
Too many lab thieves, alcoholics, and druggies.
Racism is tolerated.
Hiring freezes last for years.
advice_to_management: Hire educated managers.

name: Daniel Brown
title: Jumped the shark
pros: Great benefits compared to most companies.
cons: Poor management.
Managers will lay off good engineers.
Processes are constantly reinvented or made more complex unnecessarily.
advice_to_management: Simplify processes and provide training for good engineers.

name: Richard Taylor
title: Improving over years
pros: Work environment has significantly improved over years.
Less stress, less night and weekend coverage required from engineers.
Performance rank and review system has become more humane, with no requirement to identify a minimum number of failing performers.
cons: The environment remains somewhat stressful.
Long hours are expected.

name: Christopher Davis
title: Intel Review
pros: Good vacation package for salaried workers.
Interesting technology / global footprint.
Many development and learning opportunities.
Many non-manufacturing roles can be performed in a mostly remote capacity.
Great benefits like Sabbatical, Intel jet for employees to travel.
cons: Constant churn in leadership and organization structures since Pat Gelsinger became CEO.
Benefits have been reduced or eliminated.
Pay for non-engineering roles is not competitive.

name: Kevin Miller
title: Titanic
pros: Hey, it's a paycheck.
Decent work/life balance.
cons: Many benefits taken away.
Bonuses have been nearly nonexistent.
No clear sign Intel will ever recover.
advice_to_management: They don't listen to us low-level employees. I have given up on caring long ago.

name: Elizabeth White
title: Gross mismanagement and blatant contempt for senior employees
pros: High salary.
Interesting work.
Many locations.
Many opportunities.
cons: Profound lack of management competence and oversight.
Severe managerial incompetence is often rewarded.
Human resources is utterly incapable or interested in investigating employee issues.
Intel has become a broken and malfunctioning company.
advice_to_management: Reward technical competence. Reward productivity. Don't reward incompetence and grovelling.

name: Michelle Garcia
title: Struggling to catch up to competition
pros: Decent pay and benefits.
Hybrid work environment.
cons: Management needs a serious re-haul.
Too many VPs!
Lots of frustration at lower levels due to terrible decision making at the top.
advice_to_management: Get rid of the aging middle management. Reduce VPs by 50%.

name: Andrew Johnson
title: Interesting and rewarding work, but underpaid and undervalued
pros: The work is super cool.
I get to work with cool technologies and can own new tool development.
cons: I am underpaid compared to most other big tech companies.
Software engineers are extremely undervalued at Intel.
advice_to_management: Pay skilled engineers more so they stay here.

name: Patricia Rodriguez
title: Intel has great employees!
pros: Many employees at Intel are long-tenured.
Remarkable loyalty to the company's mission.
cons: Work-life balance varies by individual.
Some employees take on more demanding roles.
advice_to_management: Retaining top talent requires investing in their growth and development.

name: Steven Clark
title: Great Semiconductor Manufacturing to work for overall Work Life Balance
pros: Talented People.
Very structured and process-oriented company.
HR actually helps employees grow and develop skills.
cons: Some long-timers are insecure and play politics.
Competition is doing better.

name: Mark Robinson
title: Sales at Intel... is not sales
pros: Brilliant people who are generally on top of things.
Great pay and benefits.
Awesome history and culture.
cons: Absolutely impossible to determine commission per paycheck.
Quotas are out of line with forecasts.
Executives implement half-baked ideas with no meaningful revenue path.
advice_to_management: Build a bench of real sales talent and trust them to do their job.

name: Rachel Adams
title: Managers Make All The Difference
pros: Major transformation story. Communications is a strategic partner to the business.
cons: Leader of communications teams and direct managers determine your experience. If interviewing, be prepared to ask smart questions about how they manage challenges or difficult stakeholders, what team environment they are creating, what career/personal growth support they provide etc.

name: William Zhang
title: CEO and SVP EVP all are low quality and taking company to abyss
pros: WLB 100% best. Depending if you have a nice manager or not. I am lucky enough to have a great manager. Heard a lot of complaints with line managers.
cons: CEO is a nice guy. Used to be a superstar engineer in Intel. A legend. It does not mean he can be a good CEO. His vision and execution are terrible. He started talking AI one year after ChatGPT showed up. He kept and hired bad SVPs and VPs from dinosaurs like HP. Stock went down 70%, and cutting 20% workforce while competitors like MSFT, AMD, AAPL, META, AVGO all hit new highs.

name: Joseph Kim
title: Great and interesting projects. Unclear top-level leadership, strategy. Way too many VPs.
pros: There are many interesting/greatest projects. I am lucky and had such along all the long road within Intel. You can migrate/change the projects inside the company too.
cons: Current CEO is good, but the top management decisions accumulated too much damage to the company in the past. Acquisitions and sales were odd. Lost too many greatest architects and engineers in the last 10 years. Overwhelmingly too many Fellow/VPs and higher.

name: Ryan Scott
title: Great place to work if you land in the right department
pros: You can meet and network with a lot of individuals with varying degrees of background and experience. Coming from a supplier background, I got a unique perspective on wafer production and what it takes to keep up efficiency and added more troubleshooting skills to the toolbelt.
cons: Management, Management, Management. I can only speak for the departments I have worked with, but I wish Intel had taken more of a role in growing their leadership.

name: Marcus Blackwood
title: Positive Experience at Intel
pros: Good work-life balance, competitive salary, and opportunities for career growth.
cons: Large company bureaucracy can sometimes slow down decision-making processes.
advice_to_management: Streamline processes to enhance efficiency and maintain open communication channels with employees.

name: Priya Sharma
title: Mixed Feelings about Intel
pros: Access to cutting-edge technology and smart colleagues.
cons: Work can be demanding with long hours; management may not always prioritize employee well-being.
advice_to_management: Focus more on employee satisfaction and work-life balance to retain top talent.

name: Xavier Thompson
title: Concerns about Intel's Future
pros: Strong company history with significant resources.
cons: Recent strategic decisions raise questions about the company's direction and stability.
advice_to_management: Clarify long-term vision and involve employees in strategic planning to boost morale and confidence.

name: Sophia Martinez
title: Concerns about Job Security at Intel
pros: Working on cutting-edge technology with talented colleagues.
cons: Recent announcement of workforce reduction has led to uncertainty and low morale among employees.
advice_to_management: Provide clear communication and support to employees during this transition period to maintain trust and productivity.

name: Raj Patel
title: Intel's Layoff Impact on Employee Morale
pros: Access to advanced resources and a collaborative work environment.
cons: The impending layoffs have created a sense of instability, causing many to reconsider their future with the company.
advice_to_management: Focus on transparent communication and consider offering support programs for affected employees to ease the transition.

name: Zara Whitman
title: Uncertainty Following Intel's Workforce Reduction Announcement
pros: Opportunity to work on innovative projects with a diverse team.
cons: The recent news of significant job cuts has led to concerns about job security and the company's direction.
advice_to_management: Engage with employees to address their concerns and outline a clear plan for the future to restore confidence.

name: Lucas Zhang
title: Interesting and rewarding work, but underpaid and undervalued
pros: The work is super cool. I get to work with cool technologies and I can own new tool development if I want to.
cons: I am underpaid compared to most other big tech companies. Also, software engineers are extremely undervalued at Intel. The focus is on hardware, but even more than that on management. Being an incredible software engineer doesn't feel like the way to get ahead here.
advice_to_management: Pay skilled engineers more so they stay here. Make rewards based on technical contributions.

name: Olivia Blackwood
title: Intel has great employees!
pros: Many employees at Intel are long-tenured, demonstrating remarkable loyalty to the company's mission and vision by persevering through its highs and lows over the years.
cons: Work-life balance varies by individual, as some employees take on more demanding roles that naturally require greater effort and commitment.
advice_to_management: Retaining top talent requires investing time and effort in their growth and development.

name: Marcus Ramirez
title: Former Great Employer
pros: Pays well if you have a job.
cons: New executive leadership does not know the employee base. Most are outsiders.
advice_to_management: Stop paying people to leave. That was about $5 billion of wasted severance in 2024.

name: Aisha Patel
title: Sales at Intel... is not sales
pros: Brilliant people who are generally on top of things and care about making a difference. Great pay and benefits. Awesome history and culture.
cons: Absolutely impossible to determine what your commission will be per paycheck. Quotas are consistently out of line with what is forecast to Wall Street and change every six months. Business units contact your customers without warning and embarrass themselves because they don't value their hired sales team.
advice_to_management: Build a bench of real sales talent and trust them to do their job. Invest in the right infrastructure to provide better customer support through channels working on design-in. Stop hiring people who don't know how to sell into customer-facing roles; this is not a job anyone can or should do.

name: Nathan Sullivan
title: Great Semiconductor Manufacturing to work for overall Work Life Balance
pros: Talented People. Very structured and process-oriented company. HR actually helps employees grow and develop skills.
cons: Some long timers are insecure and play politics. Competition is doing better.
advice_to_management: Not provided.

name: Sophia Martinez
title: Managers Make All The Difference
pros: Major transformation story. Communications is a strategic partner to the business.
cons: Leader of communications teams and direct managers determine your experience. If interviewing, be prepared to ask smart questions about how they manage challenges or difficult stakeholders, what team environment they are creating, what career/personal growth support they provide etc.
advice_to_management: N/A

name: Alexander Wright
title: Sales at Intel... is not sales
pros: Brilliant people who are generally on top of things and care about making a difference. Great pay and benefits. Awesome history and culture.
cons: Absolutely impossible to determine what your commission will be per paycheck. Quotas are consistently out of line with what is forecast to Wall Street and change every six months. Business units contact your customers without warning and embarrass themselves because they don't value their hired sales team. Executives will swoop in with half-baked science experiments with no path to meaningful Intel revenue and bully field sales into project managing them as a favor to some old college buddy.
advice_to_management: Build a bench of real sales talent and trust them to do their job. Invest in the right infrastructure to provide better customer support through channels working on design-in. Stop hiring people who don't know how to sell into customer-facing roles; this is not a job anyone can or should do.

name: Isabella Kumar
title: Interesting and rewarding work, but underpaid and undervalued
pros: The work is super cool. I get to work with cool technologies and I can own new tool development if I want to.
cons: I am underpaid compared to most other big tech companies. Also, software engineers are extremely undervalued at Intel. The focus is on hardware, but even more than that on management. Being an incredible software engineer doesn't feel like the way to get ahead here.
advice_to_management: Pay skilled engineers more so they stay here. Make rewards based on technical contributions.

name: Aiden Blackwood
title: A Beacon of Excellence: Embracing Culture and Championing Work-Life Balance at Intel
pros: Intel shines as a paragon of excellence in the tech industry, fostering collaboration, creativity, inclusivity, and a commitment to work-life balance. Flexible work hours, remote options, and wellness programs are highlights.

name: Zara Winters
title: No longer a great place to work
pros: Severance package was generous.
cons: Demotion in roles, lack of respect for technicians, and overburdening employees with multiple jobs led to stress and health issues.
advice_to_management: Treat technicians fairly and stop overloading them with responsibilities.

name: Kai Nakamura
title: Can be fast paced, but it slowed down a lot
pros: Pay was great, coworkers were friendly, and employee rewards like quarterly bonuses and benefits were good.
cons: Slump in sales post-pandemic caused layoffs and slower work pace.

name: Lucas Reeves
title: Dynamic Leadership and Cross-Functional Excellence
pros: Strong leadership, mentorship, and a collaborative work environment with career growth opportunities.
cons: High pressure, demanding workload, and bureaucratic challenges.

name: Priya Sharma
title: Team work, inventory, documentation and networking, problem solving.
pros: Great opportunity to learn techniques.
cons: Debugging and troubleshooting power issues can be stressful.

name: Marcus Fitzgerald
title: Interesting Place
pros: Diverse teams and interesting projects.
cons: Significant layoffs despite earlier promises, changes to job roles.

name: Elena Santos
title: Intel is a great place to work.
pros: Opportunities for career growth, cutting-edge technology, and a dynamic environment.
cons: Head-count reduction.

name: Nathan Brooks
title: Challenging and rewarding but draining.
pros: Hyper-competitive culture.
cons: Management lacks vision, misaligned goals, and favoritism.

name: Olivia Thorne
title: First they lost sight of Products now they are losing sight of people
pros: Good team culture and colleagues.
cons: Frequent layoffs and focus on investors over employees.

name: Raj Malhotra
title: Amazing team and work culture but very high-paced environment with lots of responsibilities
pros: Collaborative and team-oriented culture with supportive colleagues.
cons: High-paced environment with extensive responsibilities.

name: Thaddeus Blackwood
title: Few opportunities for advancement or change and ridiculous on-call and bureaucracy
cons: New Mexico is already the lowest paying Intel site but they also have the fewest opportunities for job advancement. Ridiculous amounts of bureaucracy prevent you from doing your job and the tools and processes are so incredibly outdated that you end up spending an extra 30-40 hours each week you are on call to manually run manufacturing lines. Upper management here is also a joke and believes that engineers should be present everywhere at once, they even require engineers to have meetings in the fab because they are so dumb.

name: Octavia Whitmore
title: The best part of Intel are the Coworkers.
pros: Working for Intel in a factory setting is only as fun, exciting, rewarding as its people. If you work with a good team of technicians and engineers, then working there is amazing. Otherwise, it's a significant chore. The benefits package is the best I've ever seen.

name: Barnaby Thornton
title: Work can be rewarding but you aren't paid what you are worth.
pros: Great people.
cons: Pay growth.

name: Zephyr Blackburn
title: Amazing as I worked four times for this Company, always a different learning experience and rewarding!
pros: Empowerment and feeling part of something big and unique enriching the life’s of everyone!
cons: Balancing life and work, you want to do both at the same time, but you better schedule and allocate time for each individually!

name: Lysander Fairfax
title: Very, very busy. No work life balance
cons: Easy to get burnt out. You work around the clock. If you are a tool owner for a typical work day goes as follows: Passdown meeting, responding to hold Lots or tool recovery issues, work on your individual projects. Most cases you do not close at 5:00 pm and when you come home you can still continue working.

name: Thaddeus Blackwood
title: Large tech company with a great past but a shaky present
pros: Key technology hub and a great place to learn and grow your skills.
cons: Recent roadmap not promising and causing a shaky foundation for the company as reflected in its stock value.

name: Ambrose Whitaker
title: Great and interesting projects. Unclear top-level leadership, strategy. Way too many VPs.
pros: There are many interesting and great projects. I am lucky and had such along the long road within Intel. You can migrate/change the projects inside the company too.
cons: Current CEO is good, but the top management decisions accumulated too much damage to the company in the past. To the point that now it is difficult to recover. Acquisitions and sells were odd. Example: Intel buys McAfee for 7.7B, then sells 51% for 3.1B, and half a year later McAfee costs noticeably more. Lost too many greatest architects and engineers in the last 10 years. Overwhelmingly too many Fellow/VPs and higher, IMO. None of my colleagues and friends had even a close guess, even by giving me craziest numbers.
advice_to_management: Flatten the structure—org tree. Per my knowledge, such companies as NVIDIA have smaller org-tree height (less distance from CEO to developer).

name: Cornelius Hawthorne
title: Great place to work if you land in the right department
pros: You can meet and network with a lot of individuals with varying degrees of background and experience. Coming from a supplier background, I got a unique perspective on wafer production and what it takes to keep up efficiency and added more troubleshooting skills to the toolbelt.
cons: Management, management, management. I can only speak for the departments I have worked with, but I wish Intel had taken more of a role in growing their leadership.
advice_to_management: Read leadership books, take a personal interest in growing others around you. Build your leadership skills and add more leadership styles to your approach.

name: Bartholomew Sinclair
title: Intel Corp
pros: They pay you on time.
cons: Bad management, no transparency, only care about the bottom dollar rather than investing in employee career development—especially if they don't see you as management material.
advice_to_management: Do better.

name: Maximilian Thorne
title: Great technical work, needs more leadership streamlining
pros: Getting guidance from some truly brilliant people and if you're in the right team, very satisfying technical work.
cons: Executive leadership hasn't made great calls in the past few years. That's led to project cancellations, layoffs, and cutdowns which affects morale.

name: Octavius Blackthorn
title: Balanced pros/cons
pros: Leaders of innovation and cutting-edge technology. Numerous professional growth and development opportunities. Competitive compensation and benefits. Diverse work environment. Supports moderate focus on improving work-life balance.
cons: Work-life balance challenges in various roles. High pressure and fast-paced environment. Bureaucracy and organizational complexity. Market volatility and recent job security challenges.
advice_to_management: Foster a culture of innovation and agility. Enhance employee well-being and work-life balance. Strengthen diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives.

name: Ignatius Winterbourne
title: Cut people first
pros: Nothing
cons: They are laying off. Don't care about people. They spent too much money and are in trouble. Managers are in it for themselves and HR backs them up. Cut people to save payroll. Billions of dollars in debt. They are always behind the market, so the stock price is always low and worthless.

name: Percival Ravenscroft
title: Love it here
pros: Great pay/benefits. Work environment and safe area. Ample tools and resources to perform tasks. Low turnover. Same coworkers for the last six years. Eclectic jobs if one would like a career change within the company.
cons: Bloated management. Pointless meetings. Poor company earnings with overly ambitious expansion goals.

name: Caspian Thornfield
title: Graduate Technical Intern Experience at Intel, OR
pros: Good benefits and a great employee discount program.
cons: The upper management is very dynamic and keeps shifting goals.

name: Alaric Blackwood
title: Company has unrecognizably changed
cons: Before COVID, this was a dream job. After COVID, business got worse, and so did working conditions. Bonuses and incentives were slowly stripped away as consequences of bad decisions made by upper leadership many years ago. Stock is now worth 1/3 of what it once was. Headcount has been cut to around 1/3 of what it once was, while responsibilities have been unrealistically tripled. Disrespect and dignity went out the door years ago. Work-life balance is balanced for all work and what is left over you can have for your life. The machines are 20+ years old, and you're expected to keep them running with parts that are no longer made. You're also expected to sit through 4+ hours of meetings every day and somehow repair your machine at the same time. It's not worth your mental health. Run far away.

name: Thaddeus Ravenclaw
title: Great place to work
pros: Working at Intel was a highly rewarding and challenging experience. One of the most impressive aspects was the opportunity to work with some of the brightest minds in the industry. Intel's commitment to work-life balance was also noteworthy. The company offered flexible working hours and generous time-off policies. The on-site facilities, including gyms and cafeterias, were excellent and contributed to a positive work environment.
cons: Like any large corporation, Intel had its challenges. The size of the organization sometimes led to bureaucratic processes that could slow down decision-making. The fast-paced nature of the tech industry meant constant pressure to deliver results quickly.

name: Barnaby Nightshade
title: Collaborative and inclusive
pros: Best employer I've had! Flexible working hours depending on the role, great benefits, and a collaborative and inclusive work environment. The culture and flexible hours make Intel a great place to work for me.

name: Lysander Blackthorne
title: Mid-level managers are unqualified to manage and make poor decisions as a result.
pros: No real management for engineering roles, engineers can do whatever they want without fear of consequences.
cons: Managers are all yes men, stock price plummeting due to bad decision making.

name: Cassius Wintersmith
title: Excelente ambiente laboral y puestos de trabajo retadores
pros: Llevo casi dos años trabajando en Intel y mi experiencia personal ha sido 20/10, trabajo con profesionales de la máxima calidad y siempre están dispuestos a ayudar y a explicarte cuando hay dificultades en el camino. También el trabajo es bastante retador y uno nunca termina de aprender todas las cosas nuevas que hay para aprender en el puesto que uno ejerce.

name: Atticus Ravenwood
title: Goods and Bads
pros: Free fruit, remote working.
cons: Long hours, limited work/life balance.

name: Magnus Blackstone
title: Used to be a great company but now completely broken and destined to sink
pros: Smart people and used to be a good team, not anymore.
cons: Low-quality senior management chain since 2016. Culture is broken due to multiple layoffs and is not well organized.

name: Thaddeus Ravenscar
title: Intel is an overall great place to work
pros: Benefits are the best. Company-paid health care for the family, work-life balance, discounts, free soda, coffee, and fruit for your afternoon snack. My team was the best, we looked out for each other.
cons: There's a lot of work to get done. Intel is a large ship, and it takes a lot to keep it going. Early morning and late evening meetings can get to you at times.

name: Cornelius Blackheart
title: Easy money at the expense of sincere career growth
pros: Nothing is particularly mentally challenging. If you want to phone it in until retirement, this is the place for you.
cons: Project cancellations and layoffs are the norm. The company is disorganized and poorly qualified, focusing entirely on the process. Leadership lacks direction, and toxic positivity hinders growth.

name: Barnaby Winterbourne
title: Intel is an overall great place to work
pros: Benefits are the best. Company-paid healthcare for the family (depending on what you choose), work-life balance, discounts galore, free soda, coffee, and fruit for your afternoon snack and more. My team was the best too. We looked out for each other.
cons: There's a lot of work to get done. Intel is a large ship, and it takes a lot to keep it going. Early morning and late evening meetings can get to you at times.

name: Lysander Thornheart
title: Easy money at the expense of sincere career growth
pros: Nothing is particularly mentally challenging. If you want to phone it in until retirement, this is the place for you.
cons: Project cancellations and layoffs are the norm. The company is disorganized, poorly qualified, and lacks direction. Leadership hinders growth.

name: Thaddeus Ravensworth
title: Down to earth. People are genuinely kind, positive, forthcoming.
pros: One of the best jobs I've had. Weekly admin meetings helped us connect personally. We got to know each other better through presentations.

name: Maximilian Blackraven
title: Terrible workplace
cons: Work-life balance is almost nonexistent. Management is disorganized and lacks communication. Promotion is opaque and fosters short-term thinking. The culture is toxic and outdated.

name: Barnaby Nightingale
title: Tedious Same Work, Employees Hit and Miss
pros: Most employees are great to work with.
cons: Work is repetitive and tedious. Micromanagement makes the job frustrating.

name: Cornelius Ravenscroft
title: Good people, draining job
pros: Nice coworkers.
cons: Draining job with long hours. Bare minimum wages and repetitive tasks make it hard to have time for yourself.
